</image>   <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;e8f8bf2a.1503">   <title>Re: Problem with LogGammaFunc in WinBUGS </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;e8f8bf2a.1503</link>   <description> Hola Luis,<br><br>With the following priors your program runs:<br><br>beta ~ dexp(0.01)<br>beta1 ~ dnorm(0.0, 0.001)<br>beta2 ~ dnorm(0.0, 0.001)<br>beta3 ~ dnorm(0.0, 0.001)<br><br>I run 20,000 iterations, these are the posteriors:<br><br>node mean sd MC error 2.5% median 97.5%<br>start sample<br>beta 75.96 12.64 0.2514 52.87 75.28 102.6<br>10001 10000<br>beta1 28.14 18.05 1.576 5.097 24.19 70.63<br>10001 10000<br>beta2 -1.076 0.3769 0.0254 -1.81 -1.064 -0.3404<br>10001 10000<br>beta3 -2.78 0.7468 0.07025 -4.134 -2.781 -1.176<br>10001 10000 [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-11T10:10:08+01:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Dr. Pablo E. Verde</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;e8f8bf2a.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;e373dcd.1503">   <title>Re: Problem with LogGammaFunc in WinBUGS </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;e373dcd.1503</link>   <description> On 10/03/15 19:23, Luis wrote:<br>&gt; Hi everyone,<br>&gt;<br>&gt; I'm trying to estimate the scale parameter of a gamma distribution considering a link function with covariables as the shape parameter, but I have a problem with the logGamma function, apparently the obtained values for this function are negative, I have tried changing the initial values of the parameters and the values of the prior distributions but the problem is still the same<br>&gt;<br>&gt; I would really appreciate if there is any suggestion to make this work<br>The prior for beta1 has the median at 0, so 50% of [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-11T09:47:33+01:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Bob O'Hara</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;e373dcd.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;e8d53068.1503">   <title>Problem with LogGammaFunc in WinBUGS </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;e8d53068.1503</link>   <description> Hi everyone,<br><br>I'm trying to estimate the scale parameter of a gamma distribution considering a link function with covariables as the shape parameter, but I have a problem with the logGamma function, apparently the obtained values for this function are negative, I have tried changing the initial values of the parameters and the values of the prior distributions but the problem is still the same [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-10T18:23:34+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Luis</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;e8d53068.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;4c0e51a0.1503">   <title>Bayesian Markov Regime-Switching Models for Cointegration </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;4c0e51a0.1503</link>   <description> Dear listers,<br><br>I am intersting to write a Winbug code to &quot;Bayesian Markov Regime-Switching Models for Cointegration&quot; (http://www.scirp.org/journal/PaperInformation.aspx?PaperID=25447#.VPtHIvmG-hg).<br><br>Can anyone help me to do that?<br><br>Thanks in advance!<br><br>N.K   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-07T12:51:03+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Naceur Khraief</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;4c0e51a0.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;4d4ef383.1503">   <title>Short course: Practical Bayesian Data Analysis at the SSC, University of Reading, UK (27-29 April 2015) </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;4d4ef383.1503</link>   <description> Dear list members,<br><br>Apologies for cross-posting.<br><br>We are re-announcing the following short course, which is scheduled to take place at the Statistical Services Centre in April 2015. Summary information is given below. For more detailed information and registration forms please see http://www.reading.ac.uk/ssc/, or email statistics-courses@lists.reading.ac.uk.<br><br>Practical Bayesian Data Analysis -&gt; 27-29 April 2015. Price: 995 GBP (a 30% academic discount is available - terms and conditions apply)<br>View: http://www.reading.ac.uk/ssc/n/Short%20Courses/pracbayesian.htm [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-02T10:31:49+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>James Gallagher</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;4d4ef383.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;752705f1.1502">   <title>Some places remain on Bayesian Disease Mapping courses at University of Edinburgh June 29th - July 3rd 2015 </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;752705f1.1502</link>   <description> Some places remain on BDM courses:<br><br>Introduction to Bayesian Disease Mapping (IBDM)<br>Bayesian Disease Mapping with INLA (BDMI)<br>Advanced Bayesian Disease Mapping (ABDM)<br>**University of Edinburgh, Edinburgh, Scotland, UK June 29th - July 3rd<br>2015**<br><br>*Course content*<br>These courses are designed to provide a comprehensive introduction to<br>the area of<br>Bayesian disease mapping in applications to Public Health and Epidemiology:<br>The IBDM course will run on June29rd -30th, the BDMI course will run on<br>July 1st<br>and the ABDM course will run on July 2nd -3rd 2014. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-25T19:52:45-05:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Andrew Lawson</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;752705f1.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;74e4ace2.1502">   <title>Some places remain on Bayesian Biostatistics courses at MUSC May 2015 </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;74e4ace2.1502</link>   <description> Some places remain for the Summer Institute courses on Bayesian<br>Biostatistics at MUSC.<br><br>A course sequence of 2 workshops will be presented during the MUSC<br>Summer Institute on Research Methodology. The sequence will consist of<br>an Introductory Bayesian Biostatistics course (IBB), and an Advance<br>Bayesian Biostatistics course (ABB). The IBB course is designed to<br>provide a basic grounding in Bayesian modeling methods and hands-on<br>experience with WinBUGS, INLA and demonstration of SAS capabilities. The<br>ABB course will cover specific application areas in more depth and is<br>designed to be a continuation of the IBB course. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-22T20:01:23-05:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Andrew Lawson</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;74e4ace2.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;a66b65e3.1502">   <title>Problem in Mixture model </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;a66b65e3.1502</link>   <description> Dear Madam/ Sir<br><br>in my study I am using winBUGS program especially Mixture model. But, I need some help from you, please<br><br>I have run your coding for Mixture model, but the problem is, I couldn't set the update. The trap window will appear. I have tried so many times. But I still can't set the updater.......Kindly, please help...(the model with data is below)<br>I am looking forward to hearing from you as soon as possible [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-15T11:33:52+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>M AlHdiri</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;a66b65e3.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;1130d862.1502">   <title>problem in OpenBUGS </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;1130d862.1502</link>   <description> Dear Sir,<br>I have a problem in the last step in the code below the update tools didn't<br>work smoothly, so please help me to solve this problem.<br><br>Many thanks in advance<br><br>model {<br>for(i in 1:N){<br>#measurement equation model<br>for(j in 1:6){y[i,j]~dnorm(mu[i,j],psi[j])T(thd[j,z[i,j]],thd[j,z[i,j]+1])}<br>for(j in 7:P){y[i,j]~dnorm(mu[i,j],psi[j])T(low[z[i,j]+1],high[z[i,j]+1])}<br>mu[i,1]&lt;-mu.y[1]+xi[i,1]<br>mu[i,2]&lt;-mu.y[2]+lam[1]*xi[i,1]<br>mu[i,3]&lt;-mu.y[3]+lam[2]*xi[i,1]<br>mu[i,4]&lt;-mu.y[4]+lam[3]*xi[i,1]<br>mu[i,5]&lt;-mu.y[5]+lam[4]*xi[i,1]<br>mu[i,6]&lt;-mu.y[6]+xi[i,2]<br>mu[i,7]&lt;-mu.y[7]+lam[5]*xi[i,2]<br>mu[i,8]&lt;-mu.y[8]+lam[6]*xi[i,2]<br>mu[i,9]&lt;-mu.y[9]+lam[7]*xi[i,2]<br>mu[i,10]&lt;-mu.y[10]+eta[i]<br>mu[i,11]&lt;-mu.y[11]+lam[8]*eta[i]<br>mu[i,12]&lt;-mu.y[12]+lam[9]*eta[i]<br><br>#structural equation model<br>xi[i,1:2]~dmnorm(zero2[1:2],phi[1:2,1:2])<br>eta[i]~dnorm(nu[i],psd)<br>nu[i]&lt;-gam[1]*xi[i,1]+gam[2]*xi[i,2]+gam[3]*xi[i,1]*xi[i,1]+gam[4]*xi[i,2]*xi[i,2]<br>}# end of i<br><br>for(i in 1:2){zero2[i]&lt;-0.0}<br>#priors on loadings and coefficients<br>for(i in 1:12){mu.y[i]~dnorm(0.0,4.0)}<br>for(i in 1:9){lam[i]~dnorm(0.8,4.0)}<br>for(i in 1:4){gam[i]~dnorm(0.6,4.0)}<br>#priors on precisions<br>for(j in 1:P){<br>psi[j]~dgamma(10,8)<br>sgm[j]&lt;-1/psi[j]<br>}<br>psd~dgamma(10,8)<br>sgd&lt;-1/psd<br>phi[1:2,1:2]~dwish(R[1:2,1:2], 30)<br>phx[1:2,1:2]&lt;-inverse(phi[1:2,1:2])<br>} [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-11T19:23:43+03:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>thanoon younis</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;1130d862.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;1577a145.1502">   <title>Short course: Bayesian Analysis of Small Area Health Data using WinBUGS/GeoBUGS </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;1577a145.1502</link>   <description> Bayesian Analysis of Small Area Health Data using WinBUGS/GeoBUGS<br><br>*Start date:*<br><br>23 Mar, 2015 to 25 Mar, 2015<br><br>*Lecturers: *<br><br>Dr Marta Blangiardo and Dr Ioannis Bakolis<br><br>*Location:*<br><br>Imperial College, London<br><br>United Kingdom<br><br>Use of Bayesian methods is becoming increasingly widespread in spatial<br>epidemiology for analysing data with complex structure \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd for example,<br>hierarchical data, spatial and temporal dependence, measurement error and<br>so on. However, very few data analysts have any formal training in Bayesian<br>methods. This three-day course aims to introduce quantitative researchers<br>to the basic principles of Bayesian inference and simulation-based methods<br>for estimating Bayesian models, and to [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-09T16:39:10+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Marta Blangiardo</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;1577a145.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;546de2ce.1502">   <title>Re: Plots in Word </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;546de2ce.1502</link>   <description> I usually save my coda files and then import them in R to get my plots in<br>whatever format i need<br><br>Cheers<br><br>Guillaume<br><br>On Friday, February 6, 2015, Gene Hahn &lt;<br>0000045b5397e415-dmarc-request@jiscmail.ac.uk&gt; wrote:<br><br>&gt; One way to do this is to ensure your WinBUGS plot is active, then press<br>&gt; Alt+PrtScrn. This will take a screenshot of your WinBUGS windows. Then<br>&gt; open up Paint under Accessories in the Start Menu and paste your screenshot<br>&gt; in. Crop as needed then save to bitmap. You can now drop your bitmap file<br>&gt; into Word with no memory overload.<br>&gt;<br>> [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-06T15:32:21-03:30</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Guillaume Dauphin</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;546de2ce.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;b7d0fd97.1502">   <title>Plots in Word </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;b7d0fd97.1502</link>   <description> One way to do this is to ensure your WinBUGS plot is active, then press Alt+PrtScrn.\ufffd\ufffd This will take a screenshot of your WinBUGS windows.\ufffd\ufffd Then open up Paint under Accessories in the Start Menu and paste your screenshot in.\ufffd\ufffd Crop as needed then save to bitmap.\ufffd\ufffd You can now drop your bitmap file into Word with no memory overload.<br>You can also expand your plot before taking the screenshot by resizing its window and the graphic itself.\ufffd\ufffd You may prefer a larger size depending on your print-quality requirements. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-06T17:01:08+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Gene Hahn</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;b7d0fd97.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;9fbdb91f.1502">   <title>Re: Help with Winbugs code </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;9fbdb91f.1502</link>   <description> The posterior draws can be saved, thus allowing you to create your own plots of time series and densities. That approach is always preferable to me. Then you can do any smoothing you like, and make a figure that looks exactly the way you want. That approach, of course, also easily allows you to make any probabilistic inference about the parameters you would like, e.g., P(theta &gt; k | data), where k is any constant. [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-06T16:06:19+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Skorupski, William P</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;9fbdb91f.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;5fb8d87.1502">   <title>Re: Help with Winbugs code </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;5fb8d87.1502</link>   <description> Regarding transferring figures to Word:<br><br>I have transferred plots to Word by right-clicking on the plot and using<br>cut and paste. HOWEVER, once when I tried to copy a density plot to<br>Word for eventual use in a publication, I found that if I used a<br>moderate number of BUGS iterations, the plotted density was ragged.<br>When, instead, I used a very large number of BUGS iterations, the<br>plotted density was wonderfully smooth, but the size of the plot, in<br>kbytes, was enormous, and this large size persisted when I copied the<br>plot into a Word document. This made it [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-06T10:42:35-05:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Cory Atwood</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;5fb8d87.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;7237ee44.1502">   <title>Help with Winbugs code </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;7237ee44.1502</link>   <description> * Here below are the two questions I have:*<br><br>1.<br><br>*Is there an easier way to write the below code? I tried to use the<br>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdfor\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd loop but it didn\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt work that\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds why I had to write case by case. But<br>if I want to do it using 200 variables it will be painful. I put on<br>comments what I did using the \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdfor\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd loop unfortunately it didn\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt work.* [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-05T23:32:57-05:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>thierry wandji</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;7237ee44.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;3612eb69.1502">   <title>Bayesian Disease Mapping courses March 9th -13th MUSC Charleston USA </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;3612eb69.1502</link>   <description> A few places remain, but places are filling fast, for<br><br>Introduction to Bayesian Disease Mapping (IBDM)<br>Bayesian Disease Mapping with INLA (BDMI)<br>Advanced Bayesian Disease Mapping (ABDM)<br><br>**Offering of Introductory and Advanced BDM courses and BDM with INLA in<br>Medical University of South Carolina, Charleston, SC, USA**<br><br>Historic Charleston, South Carolina<br><br>*Course content*<br><br>These courses are designed to provide a comprehensive introduction to<br>the area of Bayesian disease mapping in applications to Public Health<br>and Epidemiology: The IBDM course will run on March 9th - 10th, the BDMI<br>course will run on March 11th<br>and the ABDM course will run [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-03T09:25:06-05:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Andrew Lawson</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;3612eb69.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;8f75cee2.1501">   <title>Bayesian Disease Mapping courses with WInBUGS and INLA at University of Edinburgh: June29th - [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-01-22T09:19:12-05:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Andrew Lawson</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;8f75cee2.1501</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;b0c4a827.1501">   <title>Help with winbugs code </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;b0c4a827.1501</link>   <description> Good Morning,<br><br>Here below is a word document where I put a code that I wrote using the<br>BUGS language and I would like your help to simplify my code since I have a<br>lot more experiment to run using Winbugs and I would also request your help<br>to write a function that make prediction. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-01-20T10:50:55-05:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>thierry wandji</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;b0c4a827.1501</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;9a967039.1501">   <title>suggestion for random model for dichotomous and continous variable </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;9a967039.1501</link>   <description> Dear all<br><br>I'm a cardiologist<br><br>very fond of meta-analysis<br><br>and trying to learn NMA<br><br>my big problem is to correctly appraise and make models function<br><br>because usually I lost myself in a lot of stuff errors<br><br>do you have any simple and efficacious problems to evaluate<br><br>1) dichotomous<br><br>2)continous<br><br>with random effect?<br><br>let me know<br><br>grazie!   </description>   <dc:date>2015-01-18T21:02:52+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Fabrizio</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;9a967039.1501</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;366ccf5e.1501">   <title>variable NA is not defined </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;366ccf5e.1501</link>   <description> Dear all<br><br>while performing many runs with bugs<br><br>I usually found the same problem<br><br>variable NA is not defined<br><br>see below the model<br><br>let me know if you can help me!<br><br>grazie<br><br>for multi-arm trials<br>model{ # *** PROGRAM STARTS<br>for(i in 1:ns){ # LOOP THROUGH STUDIES<br>w[i,1] &lt;- 0 # adjustment for multi-arm trials is zero for control arm<br>delta[i,1] &lt;- 0 # treatment effect is zero for control arm<br>mu[i] ~ dnorm(0,.0001) # vague priors for all trial baselines<br>for (k in 1:na[i]) { # LOOP THROUGH ARMS<br>r[i,k] ~ dpois(theta[i,k]) # Poisson likelihood<br>theta[i,k] <- lambda[i,k]*E[i,k] # [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-01-18T11:35:53+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Fabrizio</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;366ccf5e.1501</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;bdadf0fd.1501">   <title>longitudinal study - interface7 error </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;bdadf0fd.1501</link>   <description> Dear Winbugs users and developers!,<br><br>I am a beginner using Winbugs, the installations and update of software are ok. I follow all the procedure to run the model (see below):<br><br>- Specification tool.<br><br>- Sample monitor tool<br><br>- Update tool.<br><br>And it work properly.<br><br>The problem arise when I've tried to set Rank Monitor Tool. I set for example the variable mu node, when I click Stats the program respond with the message Interface7 in the log window, the number is random (I believed) sometime is 4, other 6 or 2. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-01-09T15:32:40+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Daniel Jardines</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;bdadf0fd.1501</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;22b5b85f.1501">   <title>Short course: Practical Bayesian Data Analysis at the SSC, University of Reading, UK (27-29 April 2015) </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;22b5b85f.1501</link>   <description> Dear list members,<br><br>Apologies for cross-posting.<br><br>We are announcing the following short course, which is scheduled to take place at the Statistical Services Centre in April 2015. Summary information is given below. For more detailed information and registration forms please see http://www.reading.ac.uk/ssc/, or email statistics-courses@lists.reading.ac.uk.<br><br>Practical Bayesian Data Analysis -&gt; 27-29 April 2015. Price: 995 GBP (a 30% academic discount is available)<br>View: http://www.reading.ac.uk/ssc/n/Short%20Courses/pracbayesian.htm [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-01-09T10:22:42+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>James Gallagher</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;22b5b85f.1501</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;a68423fe.1501">   <title>reminder: Bayesian Disease mapping (BDM) courses with WinBUGS and INLA March 9th -13 th 2015 </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;a68423fe.1501</link>   <description> Some places remain for BDM course combinations:<br><br>Introduction to Bayesian Disease Mapping (IBDM)<br>Bayesian Disease Mapping with INLA (BDMI)<br>Advanced Bayesian Disease Mapping (ABDM)<br><br>**Offering of Introductory and Advanced BDM courses and BDM with INLA in<br>Medical University of South Carolina, Charleston, SC, USA**<br><br>*Course content*<br><br>These courses are designed to provide a comprehensive introduction to<br>the area of Bayesian disease mapping in applications to Public Health<br>and Epidemiology: The IBDM course will run on March 9th - 10th, the BDMI<br>course will run on March 11th<br>and the ABDM course will run on March 12th - 13th 2015. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-01-06T13:25:58-05:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Andrew Lawson</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;a68423fe.1501</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;7b0a3e47.1501">   <title>Trap 21 in WINBUGS Using zeros trick </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;7b0a3e47.1501</link>   <description> Hi,<br><br>I'm trying to use Winbugs to estimate the parameters of a likelihood function using the zeros trick. My simple model is<br><br>model{<br>c&lt;-10000<br>n&lt;-90<br>for(i in 1:90)<br>{<br><br>zeros[i]&lt;- 0<br>zeros[i] ~ dpois(zeros.mean[i])<br>zeros.mean[i] &lt;- -l[i] +c<br><br>#Likelihood function<br><br>l[i]&lt;- (alpha.1[i]*sum(ln.x[i]) +(alpha.2[i]*sum(log(ln.y[i]) + (N*alpha.t[i]*log(beta)) - (N*gamf.1[i]) - (90*gamf.2[i]) - (beta*sum(x[i]+y[i]))<br><br>x[i] ~ dgamma(alpha.1[i], beta)<br>y[i] ~ dgamma(alpha.2[i], beta)<br>alpha.1[i] &lt;- malpha.1 * (pow( t[i+1] ,gam.v) - pow( t[i], gam.v ))<br>alpha.2[i] &lt;- malpha.2 * (pow( t[i+1] ,gam.v) - pow( t[i], gam.v ))<br>alpha.t&lt;- (alpha.1[i] + alpha.2[i])<br>gamf.1[i]&lt;- loggam(alpha.1[i])<br>gamf.2[i]&lt;- loggam(alpha.2[i]) [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-01-05T21:14:14+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Luis</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;7b0a3e47.1501</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;2df8f1d5.1501">   <title>question wrt hierarchical modeling in WinBUGS </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;2df8f1d5.1501</link>   <description> Dear all,<br><br>I'm trying to learn how to fit hierarchical models in Winbugs. As an exercise I've simulated some dose response data in R with 3 levels, which I then fed into WinBUGS.<br><br>In the following I will give:<br><br>1. The simulation setting in R<br><br>2. My WinBUGS code<br><br>After running my WinBUGS code I find the expected values for all parameters, except for:<br>-mu.l.EMAX for which the posterior distribution to me seems to similar to the prior although the pointestimate (from stat part) is as expected<br>-the omega.l.EMAX. [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-01-02T12:58:59+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Roel Straetemans</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BUGS;2df8f1d5.1501</dc:identifier> </item>   </rdf:RDF>
